open_questions.title: NoSQL
open_questions.description: What is NoSQL?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is NoSQL?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: NoSQL (Not Only SQL), refers to a category of database management systems that differ from traditional relational database systems (RDBMS) in several significant ways. These systems are designed to handle a wide variety of data models, including key-value, document, columnar, and graph formats.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The key characteristics of NoSQL
open_questions.description: What are the key characteristics of NoSQL?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the key characteristics of NoSQL?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Schema Flexibility: Dynamic schema for unstructured data, allowing changes without affecting existing data. Scalability: Designed to scale out by distributing data across multiple servers, ideal for large-scale data processing. High Performance: Optimized for specific data models and access patterns, offering efficient operations like key-value lookups and document retrievals. Data Model Variety: Supports a range of data models including document, key-value, columnar, and graph. Distributed Nature: Built for distributed environments, spreading data across multiple machines for resilience. High Availability: Techniques like replication and partitioning ensure high availability and fault tolerance. Non-Relational: Uses various models other than the traditional relational one, avoiding fixed table schemas and join operations. Ease of Development: Simplified management and more natural data models for developers. Big Data Support: Suitable for big data applications due to their capacity to handle large volumes of data efficiently. Multi-Model Support: Some systems support different data models within the same database engine.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The main differences between NoSQL and
open_questions.description: What are the main differences between NoSQL and traditional relational databases?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the main differences between NoSQL and traditional relational databases?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Data Model: Relational databases use structured, table-based models; NoSQL uses varied models like key-value, document, columnar, and graph. Schema Flexibility: Relational databases require a fixed schema; NoSQL offers schema flexibility. Scalability: Relational databases traditionally scale vertically (enhancing a single server); NoSQL is designed for horizontal scalability (across many servers). Query Language: SQL is used in relational databases; NoSQL employs various querying languages and APIs. Transaction Support: Relational databases support strong ACID properties; NoSQL may have weaker consistency models for better performance. Consistency and Reliability: Relational databases focus on strong consistency; NoSQL emphasizes high availability and partition tolerance. Use Cases: Relational databases are ideal for complex queries and transactional integrity; NoSQL is better for large, diverse data sets and scalable applications. Data Integrity: Relational databases enforce data integrity with constraints; NoSQL relies more on application-level data integrity.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The CAP theorem in the context
open_questions.description: Explain the CAP theorem in the context of NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the CAP theorem in the context of NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The CAP theorem, in the context of NoSQL databases, states that a distributed database system can only simultaneously provide two out of the following three properties: Consistency: Every read receives the most recent write or an error. Availability: Every request receives a response, without guarantee of it containing the most recent write. Partition Tolerance: The system continues to operate despite network partitions.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es it mean for a NoSQL
open_questions.description: What does it mean for a NoSQL database to be "AP," "CP," or "CA"?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What does it mean for a NoSQL database to be "AP," "CP," or "CA"?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: AP (Availability and Partition Tolerance): The system prioritizes availability and partition tolerance, meaning it remains operational and accessible despite network failures, but may not always provide the most recent data (consistency can be compromised). CP (Consistency and Partition Tolerance): The system ensures data consistency and operates despite partitions, but may sacrifice availability (not all requests are guaranteed a response). CA (Consistency and Availability): This combination is less common in distributed systems, as it implies the system maintains data consistency and availability but may not handle network partitions effectively. In practice, a true CA system is hard to achieve in a distributed environment.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The BASE acronym in NoSQL databases.
open_questions.description: Explain the BASE acronym in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the BASE acronym in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: BASE stands for Basically Available, Soft state, Eventually consistent Basically Available: The system guarantees availability in terms of being able to perform read and write operations. Soft State: The state of the system may change over time, even without input, due to eventual consistency. Eventual Consistency: The system will become consistent over time, given that no new updates are made to the data.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es BASE differ from the ACID
open_questions.description: How does BASE differ from the ACID properties of relational databases?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How does BASE differ from the ACID properties of relational databases?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: BASE, used in NoSQL databases, differs from ACID properties of relational databases in the following ways: ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability): Ensures reliable transactions, data integrity, and consistency in every state. BASE (Basically Available, Soft State, Eventual Consistency): Focuses on high availability and tolerance to network partitions, with eventual consistency over immediate data accuracy.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The common types of NoSQL databases
open_questions.description: What are the common types of NoSQL databases?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the common types of NoSQL databases?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Document-Oriented: Stores data in document-like structures (e.g., JSON, XML). Example: MongoDB. Key-Value Stores: Simple, uses key-value pairs for storage. Example: Redis. Column-Family Stores: Stores data in columns rather than rows. Example: Cassandra. Graph Databases: Designed for data represented as graphs. Example: Neo4j.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You choose one type of NoSQL
open_questions.description: When would you choose one type of NoSQL databases over another?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "When would you choose one type of NoSQL databases over another?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Document-Oriented: When dealing with semi-structured data or JSON documents, and needing flexible schemas. Key-Value Stores: For simple, high-speed operations on large amounts of data with simple access patterns. Column-Family Stores: When handling large datasets with column-oriented queries, suitable for analytics and time-series data. Graph Databases: Ideal for interconnected data and complex relationships, like social networks or recommendation engines.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

Content management systems, e-commerce applications, and situations where each record can be unique.

open_questions.title: The characteristics and use cases of
open_questions.description: Explain the characteristics and use cases of a Key-Value Stores NoSQL database.?

referenceAnswers.text: Characteristics of Key-Value Stores NoSQL Database: Simple Data Model: Data is stored as key-value pairs, where a unique key is associated with a value. High Performance: Optimized for quick retrieval and storage, offering fast read/write operations. Scalability: Easily scalable, often used for distributed storage systems. Limited Query Capabilities: Typically, they support basic operations like get, put, and delete based on keys. Use Cases: Session Storage: Ideal for storing user session data in web applications. Caching: Frequently used for high-speed caching solutions. Real-Time Recommendations: Used in scenarios requiring quick data access, like real-time recommendation engines. User Profiles and Preferences: Suitable for storing and retrieving user-specific information.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The characteristics and use cases of
open_questions.description: Explain the characteristics and use cases of a Column-Family Stores NoSQL database.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the characteristics and use cases of a Column-Family Stores NoSQL database.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Characteristics of Column-Family Stores NoSQL Database: Column-Oriented Storage: Data is stored in columns instead of rows, optimizing for read/write of specific data subsets. Scalability: Highly scalable for large datasets and distributed systems. Flexible Schema: Allows variation in columns across different rows. Efficient Queries: Optimized for queries over large datasets and aggregation operations. Use Cases: Big Data Analytics: Suitable for handling and analyzing large volumes of data. Time-Series Data: Ideal for time-stamped data like IoT data, financial data, or event logging. Content Management Systems: Useful for managing content with variable attributes. Recommendation Engines: Efficient for processing user behavior and preferences for recommendations.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The characteristics and use cases of

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Characteristics of Graph Databases NoSQL Database: Graph Structure: Data is stored as nodes (entities), edges (relationships), and properties. Relationship-First Approach: Optimized for handling complex relationships and network structures. Flexible Schema: Adaptable to various data models, accommodating evolving structures. Efficient Relationship Queries: Excellent for traversing and querying interconnected data. Use Cases: Social Networks: Ideal for managing complex and dynamic social connections. Recommendation Systems: Effective in suggesting content based on user relationships and preferences. Fraud Detection: Useful in detecting patterns and relationships indicative of fraudulent activities. Network and IT Operations: Applicable for mapping and analyzing network topologies and dependencies.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of eventual consistency in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of eventual consistency in distributed NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of eventual consistency in distributed NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Eventual consistency in distributed NoSQL databases refers to a model where database updates are propagated across nodes over time, meaning all nodes will eventually hold the same data, but not necessarily immediately. This approach improves availability and performance at the cost of immediate data consistency.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es eventual consistency differ from strong
open_questions.description: How does eventual consistency differ from strong consistency?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How does eventual consistency differ from strong consistency?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Eventual consistency allows for temporary data inconsistencies across nodes, resolving over time for better availability and performance. Strong consistency ensures data is immediately consistent across all nodes, prioritizing accuracy but potentially reducing performance and availability.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Discuss the challenges of data modeling
open_questions.description: Discuss the challenges of data modeling in NoSQL databases compared to relational databases. How do you approach data modeling in a NoSQL context?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "Discuss the challenges of data modeling in NoSQL databases compared to relational databases. How do you approach data modeling in a NoSQL context?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Schema Flexibility: NoSQL's schema-less nature requires a different approach to structuring data, often needing more planning to ensure efficient access and scalability. Data Relationships: Without built-in relational integrity, managing data relationships in NoSQL can be complex, often requiring application-level handling. Query Complexity: NoSQL databases lack the standardized query language and complex join capabilities of SQL, making some query operations more challenging. Data Consistency: Ensuring data consistency across distributed systems (in eventual consistency models) is more challenging compared to the ACID properties of relational databases.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A composite key in NoSQL databases,
open_questions.description: What is a composite key in NoSQL databases, and why might you use it in data modelling?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a composite key in NoSQL databases, and why might you use it in data modelling?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A "composite key" in NoSQL databases is a key formed by combining two or more attributes to create a unique identifier for each record. It is used in data modeling to efficiently access and query data, particularly in scenarios where data is organized by more than one attribute, enhancing query performance and enabling more complex data relationships. For example, in an e-commerce application, a composite key might include a product's category and SKU to ensure uniqueness across categories.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between sharding and replication
open_questions.description: What is the difference between sharding and replication in NoSQL databases?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between sharding and replication in NoSQL databases?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Sharding is the practice of horizontally partitioning data across multiple servers or nodes to distribute the load and improve scalability. Replication, on the other hand, involves creating copies of data on multiple nodes to enhance fault tolerance and availability. You would use sharding for improving read and write scalability and replication for ensuring data redundancy and high availability.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of consistent hashing in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of consistent hashing in the context of distributed NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of consistent hashing in the context of distributed NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Consistent Hashing is a technique used to distribute data evenly across multiple nodes or partitions in a distributed database. It ensures that when a node is added or removed, only a minimal amount of data needs to be relocated. Consistent Hashing is important for load balancing and maintaining data distribution in a dynamic and scalable environment.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some consistent hashing techniques.
open_questions.description: Name some consistent hashing techniques.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some consistent hashing techniques.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Ring-Based Hashing: Data is mapped onto a ring-like space, and each node in the system is responsible for a segment of the ring. Virtual Nodes: Introduces virtual replicas of nodes in the hash space to distribute load more evenly and handle node failures efficiently. Consistent Hashing with Bounded Loads: A variation that balances load across nodes while maintaining the benefits of consistent hashing. Jump Consistent Hashing: A stateless, scalable hashing algorithm that provides a good distribution of keys and minimal movement when nodes join or leave. Rendezvous (HRW) Hashing: Determines node assignments based on highest scores calculated using a hash function, offering simplicity and effectiveness in load distribution.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Discuss the challenges and strategies for
open_questions.description: Discuss the challenges and strategies for handling data consistency in distributed NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Discuss the challenges and strategies for handling data consistency in distributed NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Challenges: Eventual Consistency: Ensuring eventual data uniformity across nodes can lead to temporary data discrepancies. Network Partitions: Handling data operations during network failures or splits is complex. Concurrency Control: Managing simultaneous data operations without traditional locking mechanisms. Strategies: Consistency Levels: Implementing tunable consistency levels (e.g., strong, eventual) based on application requirements. Versioning and Conflict Resolution: Using data versioning to manage conflicts in data updates. Read and Write Quorums: Setting quorum policies for read and write operations to balance consistency and availability. Data Replication Strategies: Employing replication techniques to enhance consistency and fault tolerance.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of tombstones in NoSQL
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of tombstones in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of tombstones in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Tombstones in NoSQL databases are markers indicating that a data record has been deleted or updated. They are used to manage data consistency across distributed systems, ensuring that deleted or updated items are properly replicated and old data is not resurrected during synchronization or recovery processes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The advantages and disadvantages of using

referenceAnswers.text: Advantages: Scalability: Efficiently scales to handle large volumes of data. High Throughput: Supports high read/write speeds, ideal for big data applications. Flexible Schema: Column-family oriented, accommodating evolving data structures. Disadvantages: Complexity: Can be complex to set up and manage. Limited Querying: Lacks the sophisticated querying capabilities of traditional RDBMS. Consistency Trade-offs: Emphasizes availability and partition tolerance, which can lead to eventual consistency challenges.

open_questions.title: Polyglot persistence in the context of
open_questions.description: What is polyglot persistence in the context of NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is polyglot persistence in the context of NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Polyglot persistence refers to the practice of using multiple NoSQL databases within the same application to store different types of data optimally. Each database is chosen based on its strengths and suitability for specific data models and access patterns. This approach allows applications to benefit from the best features of various databases while avoiding the limitations of a one-size-fits-all solution.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: DOM
open_questions.description: What is document-level locking in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is document-level locking in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Explain in the browser runtime context - Give a practical example Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Explain in the browser runtime context; Give a practical example. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Document-level locking in NoSQL databases is a mechanism that locks individual documents during transactions to prevent concurrent modifications, ensuring data integrity and consistency. This granular approach allows multiple operations to occur in parallel while avoiding conflicts and data corruption.
keyPoints: Explain in the browser runtime context
Give a practical example

open_questions.title: Point-in-time backups in NoSQL databases
open_questions.description: What are point-in-time backups in NoSQL databases?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are point-in-time backups in NoSQL databases?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Point-in-time backups in NoSQL databases are snapshots of the database's state at a specific moment. These backups allow for data recovery up to the exact time the backup was taken, providing a means to restore data in case of corruption, loss, or other issues.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Normalization in NoSQL databases involves organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity. Although less common compared to relational databases, it can be used in NoSQL to optimize data structure, enhance consistency, and minimize duplication.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of denormalization in NoSQL
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of denormalization in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of denormalization in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Denormalization in NoSQL databases refers to the practice of intentionally combining data from multiple tables into a single, larger table. This reduces the need for complex joins, improving read performance and scalability, but can increase data redundancy and storage requirements.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Schemaless databases in the context of NoSQL refer to systems where the data can be stored without a predefined schema. This means the structure of data can vary from one record to another, providing flexibility to accommodate different types of data and allowing modifications without affecting the entire database.

open_questions.title: Write amplification in the context of
open_questions.description: What is write amplification in the context of NoSQL databases?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is write amplification in the context of NoSQL databases?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Write amplification in NoSQL databases refers to the phenomenon where the amount of data physically written to storage is significantly more than the logical data size being written. This occurs due to database background processes like compaction and replication, impacting storage efficiency and write performance. Techniques to mitigate write amplification include batch processing, write-ahead logs, and compaction strategies.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of offline-first applications and
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of offline-first applications and how NoSQL databases can support them.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of offline-first applications and how NoSQL databases can support them.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Offline-first applications are designed to work seamlessly both online and offline, with data synchronization when connectivity is restored. NoSQL databases can support offline-first applications by: Local Data Storage: Embedding within the application to store data locally, enabling functionality without internet connectivity. Data Synchronization: Efficiently syncing local data with the server once online, handling conflicts and data merging. Flexible Data Models: Adapting to varied data structures, useful for changes during offline use. Scalability and Performance: Providing quick data access and updates for a responsive user experience in offline mode. Conflict Resolution: Managing concurrent updates and data inconsistencies between offline and online states.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Batch processing, and how can NoSQL

referenceAnswers.text: Batch processing refers to executing a series of data-processing jobs or tasks simultaneously or sequentially without manual intervention. NoSQL databases support batch processing by efficiently handling large volumes of data, providing capabilities for bulk data import/export, and offering features to process and analyze big data sets in batches, thus enhancing performance and throughput.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The principles of event sourcing and
open_questions.description: Explain the principles of event sourcing and CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation) and how they relate to NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the principles of event sourcing and CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation) and how they relate to NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Event Sourcing: This principle involves storing changes to application state as a sequence of events. In NoSQL databases, it enables efficient event logging and replaying these events to reconstruct application state. CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation): CQRS separates read and write operations into different interfaces. This complements NoSQL's scalability and performance, allowing optimized models for reading and writing, and can be particularly effective in event-sourced systems.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Bloom filter
open_questions.description: What is a Bloom filter?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a Bloom filter?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Bloom filter is a probabilistic data structure used to test whether an element is a member of a set. It provides fast membership tests but may produce false positives. In NoSQL databases, Bloom filters are used for optimizing data access. For example, they can be used to quickly determine whether a requested item exists in a distributed cache or in a large dataset without retrieving the entire data.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Graph traversal and graph algorithms in

referenceAnswers.text: In the context of graph databases, graph traversal refers to the process of visiting nodes (vertices) and edges in a graph, typically to search or analyze data. Graph algorithms are complex computations performed on graphs, like finding shortest paths, detecting cycles, or identifying network centrality, used to extract insights and relationships from graph-structured data.

open_questions.title: Name some popular graph algorithms.
open_questions.description: Name some popular graph algorithms.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some popular graph algorithms.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Dijkstra's Algorithm: Finds the shortest path between nodes in a graph. Breadth-First Search (BFS): Explores the graph level by level to find the shortest path or traverse the graph. Depth-First Search (DFS): Explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking, used in pathfinding and ordering. A* Algorithm: Used for pathfinding and graph traversal, optimizing for the shortest possible path. PageRank: Google's algorithm for ranking web pages in search results based on link structures. Kruskals and Prims Algorithms: Used for finding the Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) of a graph. Bellman-Ford Algorithm: Computes shortest paths from a single source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted graph. Floyd-Warshall Algorithm: Finds shortest paths between all pairs of vertices in a graph.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of compensating transactions in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of compensating transactions in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of compensating transactions in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Compensating transactions in NoSQL databases are operations designed to undo or mitigate the effects of a previous transaction, particularly in systems that don't support traditional rollback mechanisms. They are used to maintain data integrity in the event of partial transaction failures or in distributed environments where ACID transactions are not feasible.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The leader-follower replication model in NoSQL
open_questions.description: Explain the leader-follower replication model in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the leader-follower replication model in NoSQL databases.?" open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The leader-follower replication model in NoSQL databases involves designating one node as the "leader" for handling write operations, while "followers" replicate these changes. Read operations can be distributed across leader and followers. This model ensures data consistency and high availability.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of read-your-writes consistency in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of read-your-writes consistency in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of read-your-writes consistency in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Read-your-writes consistency in NoSQL databases ensures that a client reading data immediately after it writes will see the latest write. This consistency model guarantees that updates made by a client are immediately visible to subsequent read operations by the same client.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of distributed locking in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of distributed locking in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of distributed locking in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Distributed locking in NoSQL databases is a mechanism used to manage access to shared resources in a distributed environment. When multiple nodes or processes need to modify the same data, a distributed lock ensures that only one node can make changes at a time, preventing conflicts and data inconsistencies. Here's how it typically works: Acquiring a Lock: When a node wants to modify a shared resource, it requests a lock. If the lock is available, the node acquires it, preventing other nodes from making conflicting changes. Performing Operations: With the lock acquired, the node can safely perform its operations on the shared resource. Releasing the Lock: Once the operations are completed, the lock is released, making it available for other nodes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Materialized view in NoSQL databases
open_questions.description: What is materialized view in NoSQL databases?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is materialized view in NoSQL databases?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A materialized view in NoSQL databases is a precomputed data set derived from a primary data source, stored for quick query access. It represents a snapshot of the data at a specific point in time, optimized for certain types of queries, improving performance by reducing the need for on-the-fly computation. For example, in a social media application, a materialized view can store the total number of likes on each user's post, allowing for quick retrieval of this information without aggregating data each time.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of
open_questions.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of using NoSQL databases for time-series data storage.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of using NoSQL databases for time-series data storage.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Advantages: Scalability: Handles large volumes of data efficiently. High Performance: Fast read/write capabilities, suitable for high-frequency data. Schema Flexibility: Adapts to varying data structures common in time-series data. Disadvantages: Complex Queries: Limited compared to SQL databases, especially for complex aggregations. Data Consistency: Some NoSQL databases offer eventual consistency, which can be a drawback for time-sensitive data. Maintenance Overhead: Can require more management and tuning compared to traditional databases.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some NoSQL databases suitable for
open_questions.description: Name some NoSQL databases suitable for time-series data.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some NoSQL databases suitable for time-series data.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: For time-series data, databases specifically designed to handle time-stamped information are most suitable. These include: InfluxDB: Optimized for high write loads and data retrieval efficiency in time-series data. TimescaleDB: An extension of PostgreSQL, it combines the reliability and powerful query capabilities of SQL with time-series data optimization. Prometheus: Popular in monitoring and alerting, particularly in systems and network monitoring. Graphite: Useful for storing and tracking the performance of computer systems. Apache Cassandra: With time-series data modeling, it offers scalability and high availability. Kdb+: Known for its high performance in financial time-series databases.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of linearizability in distributed
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of linearizability in distributed systems and how it relates to data consistency in NoSQL databases.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of linearizability in distributed systems and how it relates to data consistency in NoSQL databases.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Linearizability in distributed systems is a consistency model ensuring that operations (like reads and writes) on a NoSQL database appear instantaneous and in a specific sequence. It guarantees that every read reflects the most recent write. Achieving linearizability in NoSQL databases involves balancing data consistency with system performance and availability, often leading to trade-offs as per the CAP theorem.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
